conversation.content: [hesitantly] I didn't know you worked here now, honestly I would have gone somewhere else if I'd known, but my usual place is booked solid for the next three weeks.
[quietly] It's fine, David, I've been here since April. [pause] Just fill out the intake form and tell me what service level you want for the Accord.
[awkwardly] Right, the full interior and exterior package, I guess. [clears throat] The coffee stain on the passenger seat won't come out no matter what I try.
[professionally] That's from the road trip to Portland last summer, I remember when you spilled it trying to change the music while driving through that construction zone.
[softly] You remember that.
[quickly] Standard detail takes four hours.
[wandering] Your hair is different, shorter, it looks good on you. [sighs] Sorry, I shouldn't have said that, I know we agreed to stay out of each other's lives.
[firmly] The waiting area has coffee and WiFi if you're staying, or you can leave your number and we'll text when it's ready for pickup. [pause]
I'll wait, if that's okay, I don't have anywhere else to be today and [exhales] maybe we could talk when you're on break or something.
[withdrawing] I don't take breaks.
[sincerely] Look, I know I messed everything up with us, moving for that job without really talking it through, assuming you'd just follow me to Seattle without asking what you wanted.
[bitter] You made your choice, David, and now I'm here detailing cars instead of finishing my nursing degree because I spent all my savings trying to make long distance work. [shaky voice]
I came back though.
[very quietly] Six months too late, after I'd already rebuilt my whole life without you in it, after I learned how to sleep alone again and stopped checking my phone every five minutes.
[regretful] The Seattle job was a mistake, the money wasn't worth losing you, losing us, and I think about that every single morning when I wake up in that empty apartment.
[exhausted] Please don't do this here, not at my workplace where I have to see you and pretend everything is professional and fine when nothing about this is fine.
[desperately] I still have that playlist you made me for the drive up there, the one with all the songs from our first year together, and I can't bring myself to delete it.
[trembling] Your keys. [pause] Just give me your keys and go wait in the lobby, I'll handle your car myself so you don't have to deal with the other techs.
[very softly] I never stopped loving you, Jen, I just got really good at pretending I did because the alternative was admitting I threw away the best thing in my life.

[crying while speaking] The Accord will be ready at three, we'll remove the coffee stain and detail everything else, and after today please find somewhere else to get your car serviced. [long pause] Please.

scenario: An ex-boyfriend brings his car to be detailed at the shop where his ex now works, their first encounter six months after a painful breakup.
